title: Colo. beer industry brews inspiration for artists
text:
Colo. beer industry brews inspiration for artists Local artist Karen Canino demonstrates her process for making beads from beer bottle caps. Valerie Mosley/The Coloradoan Erin Udell , erinudell@coloradoan.com 11:59 p.m. MDT October 15, 2015 Buy Photo Fort Collins artist Karen Canino makes beads for her handmade jewelry out of bottle caps. Some of her work is displayed at her studio in this photograph taken Wednesday. (Photo: Valerie Mosley/The Coloradoan) Buy Photo 3 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
You see bottle caps, Karen Canino sees beads. 
The Fort Collins artist found beauty in caps from Fort Collins breweries and others across the world years ago, and has since modified and finally perfected her process of hammering them into works of jewelry art. 
And she’s not alone. 
The craft brewing industry has been on the rise since the mid-1980s, as the ranks of brewpubs and microbreweries doubled from 1,521 in 2008 to more than 3,200 in 2014, according to the Brewers Association, a Boulder-based craft beer trade group. 
In Fort Collins alone, there are almost 20, and the booming industry has started to reflect itself in the work of artists like Canino. 
“I think it just relates to how the brewery culture itself has exploded, especially in Fort Collins,” Fort Collins illustrator Allie Ogg said. 
Ogg, 30, is an artist and illustrator who’s also worked at Equinox Brewing for the past four years. 
Last year, she was approached by local writer and publisher Karla Oceanak who had an idea for a book, a twist on “Good Night Moon.” Thus “Good Night Brew,” a “pitcher book” for adults, was born. 
“People around here, they love their local breweries,” Canino said after detailing her process of making bottle caps into beads. “They like their beer.
